newsitem.title: UK: Mideast dirty tankers steady, Med softens.
newsitem.headline: Mideast dirty tankers steady, Med softens.

text.p: Middle East dirty tanker rates were little changed on Wednesday, while the Mediterranean market showed further signs of softening after its recent spike, brokers said.
The West African sector was fairly lively, with 130,000 tonne vessels to the U.S. Gulf fixed at W92.5/95, amid signs that rates could edge up.

"There has been a reasonable number of fixtures today and there isn't that much tonnage around (in West Africa) to the 28th or 30th (Feb). I think we could see rates up to W97.5 in the next day or two," one broker said.
Trips from the North Sea to the U.S. continued to shadow the West African sector, with very large crude carriers (VLCCs) at W60 and 130,000 tonne ships around W90/92.5.

Brokers reported large numbers of ships in the Med and low enquiry levels. They put 80,000 tonners at about W125, down five points, and 130,000 tonners at W85/90, five to 10 points lower than Tuesday.
VLCCs from the Middle East remained steady after reaching a plateau in recent weeks.
Mideast/west voyages were fixed at W50, Mideast/Japan at about W62.5/65 and Mideast/Singapore at W50, brokers said.
The inter-U.K./Cont sector was quiet with rates for 80,000 tonners assessed at about W100/102.5. "To get rates up, we would need a lot of enquiry and I can't see that happening," one broker said.
Fuel oil was also inactive, with rates assessed unchanged at W210 for 25,000 tonne cargoes inter-U.K./Cont and W190 cross-Med.

The U.S. sector was softer, with plenty of tonnage available in the Caribbean. "There were a number of swaps with each one refixed at slightly lower numbers to be sure of getting covered," one broker said.
He said 70,000 tonne crude cargoes were being fixed at W145, down about five points, with 50,000 tonnes of fuel oil done at W170.
